Package pec

Class PEC

  • java.lang.Object
    • pec.PEC
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IPEC

    public class PEC
extends java.lang.Object
implements IPEC
    The class PEC implements the PEC interface. It stores and manages the events waiting to take place, by offering an API to add, get and remove events from the PEC.
    Author:
    Manuel Serra

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field Description
      (package private) java.util.Comparator<Event> comparator
      An Event comparator that compares Events by their timestamp.
      (package private) java.util.PriorityQueue<Event> pec
      PriorityQueue of Events where the events waiting to take place are stored in order of timestamp.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      PEC​(int initCap, java.util.Comparator<Event> comp)
      Constructor method for a PEC object.

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods

      void addEvent​(Event ev)
      This method adds an element to the PEC, which is placed in the position corresponding to it's order by timestamp.

      This method retrieves the first element in the PEC.

      This method retrieves the number of elements in the PEC.

      This method checks if the PEC is empty.
      void removeIndEvents​(Individual ind)
      This method removes the events associated with the input Individual from the PEC.
      java.lang.String toString​()
      Redefinition of the toString method in order to print the elements of the PEC implemented as a Priority Queue.

    • Constructor Detail

      • PEC

        public PEC​(int initCap,
           java.util.Comparator<Event> comp)
        Constructor method for a PEC object. A Priority Queue is instantiated using an EventComparator.
        Parameters:
        initCap - is the initial capacity of the PEC.
        comp - is the comparator with which the events will be sorted.

    • Method Detail

      • getNextEvent

        public Event getNextEvent​()
        This method retrieves the first element in the PEC.
        Specified by:
        getNextEvent in interface IPEC
        Returns:
        An Event object.

      • addEvent

        public void addEvent​(Event ev)
        This method adds an element to the PEC, which is placed in the position corresponding to it's order by timestamp. If the input event has a negative timestamp it is not added to the PEC. Such an approach is useful when the random time given to an event is posterior to the associated individual's death.
        Specified by:
        addEvent in interface IPEC
        Parameters:
        ev - is the event to be added to the PEC.

      • isEmptyPEC

        public boolean isEmptyPEC​()
        This method checks if the PEC is empty. It essentially provides the isEmpty() method from java.util.PriorityQueue as a public method. It allows the PEC to be re-implemented using a different data structure without the need to change the code where the PEC is used, as long as the API is followed.
        Returns:
        A boolean that is true if the PEC is empty and false otherwise.

      • getSize

        public int getSize​()
        This method retrieves the number of elements in the PEC. It allows the PEC to be re-implemented using a different data structure without the need to change the code where the PEC is used, as long as the API is followed.
        Returns:
        An int with the size of the PEC.

      • removeIndEvents

        public void removeIndEvents​(Individual ind)
        This method removes the events associated with the input Individual from the PEC. Since the PEC is implemented as a PriorityQueue an iterator is used. The events to remove are identified by the ID of the individual associated with them.
        Specified by:
        removeIndEvents in interface IPEC
        Parameters:
        ind - is the individual associated with the events to be removed.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString​()
        Redefinition of the toString method in order to print the elements of the PEC implemented as a Priority Queue.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
